provenance.note: Probably inherited by Catherine Blake, William Blake's wife, in 1827; probably inherited by Frederick Tatham in 1831; the London dealer Joseph Hogarth by c. 1843; briefly in the possession of John Ruskin, c. 1843, to whom the work was offered by Hogarth through the agency of George Richmond; Sold Southgate and Barrett auction, London, 23 June 1854, lot 5509, titled "Archimedes" (8s. to the dealer Henry Palser); Samuel Prince, sold from his collection Sotheby's, 11 Dec. 1865, lot 273, titled "Newton" (£5.10s. to the dealer Halstead); R. M. de Forest by 1919; J. W. Bartlett; sold American Art Association auction, New York, 30 Jan. 1924, lot 66 (no price record); George C. Smith, Jr., by 1927; sold Parke-Bernet auction, New York, 2 Nov. 1938, lot 95 ($1800 to the Philadelphia book dealer Charles Sessler, probably acting on behalf of Mrs. William T. Tonner); by bequest from Tonner to the Lutheran Church in America in 1971; on deposit at the Philadelphia Museum of Art since c. 1985.

objnote.p: In "Newton," the great scientist is represented as a heroically proportioned youth sitting at the bottom of the ocean. Newton bends forward to measure a line(?) on a partly unrolled scroll. Taken together, his environment and his actions indicate the descent of the human form divine into materialism and abstraction.
The title, "NEWTON," inscribed on the rock behind the figure upper left, is almost certainly not by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Newton, sitting in an underwater seascape, bends forward sharply at the waist to measure or draw on a partially unrolled scroll. He uses dividers or compasses, which he holds in his left hand. With his right index finger he points toward a line on the scroll that may also be a shadow. His hair is short and curly, and his body is youthful and muscular. His one pictured eye looks downward in an expression of concentration. Although he is nude, drapery falls from behind his body and covers the edge of the unrolled portion of the scroll. Newton sits on a ledge projecting from a cliff, large rock, or reef of some kind that appears to be covered with undersea vegetation that resembles moss. The dark areas along the margin upper left suggest a cave.

component.illusobjdesc: A youthful and muscular Newton, sitting in an underwater seascape, bends forward sharply at the waist to measure or draw on a partially unrolled scroll. He is seen in right profile, with his head facing down. He uses dividers or compasses, which he holds in his left hand between his thumb and at least two fingers. His left arm must be bent at the elbow, and his wrist is bent downward to hold the compasses. His right arm is extended downward, and with his right index finger he points toward a line and/or a shadow on the scroll. Fingers, hands, feet, and right ear (the last partly covered by Newton's curly hair) are carefully delineated. His left leg is bent back, and his left foot rests behind his right. His hair is short and curly. His one pictured eye, the right, looks downward in an expression of concentration. Although he is nude, drapery (part of a cloak or robe?) falls from behind his body and covers the edge of the unrolled portion of the scroll.
Newton holds dividers or compasses in his left hand, and uses them to measure on a partly unrolled scroll.
Newton measures on a partially unrolled scroll. The rolled portion, on the far right, is coiled into a spiral.
A line, or perhaps a shadow, appears on the scroll left and right of Newton's right index finger.
Newton sits on a ledge projecting from a cliff or a large rock, possibly part of a reef or undersea mountain. The dark area behind Newton along the left margin of the design might indicate a cave.
The cliff, rock, or reef on which Newton sits and the ground (or floor of the ocean) on the right is encrusted with indeterminate vegetation, perhaps the undersea equivalents of mosses or lichens.

Newton is probably pictured under the ocean, although this is more clearly suggested by the impression in the Tate Collection, Butlin 306. This may be the sea of time and space in Blake's mythological imagery.

lg.l: NEWTONThe center horizontal of "E" was not inscribed. This inscribed title was almost certainly not written by Blake. When sold at auction in 1854, the work was title "Archimedes," but was given its proper title of "Newton" in an 1865 auction. Thus it seems likely that the title was not present in 1854; it may have been added to the work between 1854 and 1865 or at some later date.
